title: 110_hr1944
content: The Act titled "Veterans Traumatic Brain Injury Treatment Act of 2007" amends Chapter 17 of title 38, United States Code, to include screening, rehabilitation, and treatment for traumatic brain injury under a new subchapter. The Act establishes a screening program for veterans eligible for hospital care to screen for traumatic brain injury symptoms. The Secretary must submit an annual report on the number of veterans screened, prevalence of symptoms, and recommendations for care. Additionally, a comprehensive program for long-term traumatic brain injury rehabilitation will be developed and implemented. The Act establishes a comprehensive program for long-term traumatic brain injury rehabilitation for veterans, including residential, community, and home-based components. The program will be carried out in four geographically dispersed polytrauma network sites, and eligibility criteria include serving in combat operations after the Persian Gulf War. The Act establishes a program for long-term traumatic brain injury rehabilitation for veterans who served in combat operations after the Persian Gulf War. Eligibility criteria include a diagnosis of moderate to severe traumatic brain injury and the inability to manage daily activities without assistance. The Secretary is required to submit annual reports on the program's operation, number of veterans served, and annual costs. Additionally, Traumatic Brain Injury Transition Offices are established under the Act. The House of Representatives requires annual reports on a program for long-term traumatic brain injury rehabilitation for veterans. Traumatic Brain Injury Transition Offices are established to coordinate healthcare and services for veterans with moderate to severe traumatic brain injuries. Cooperative agreements can be made with public or private entities for neurobehavioral rehabilitation programs. Additionally, a Traumatic Brain Injury Registry will be established and maintained by the Secretary. The Secretary will establish a Traumatic Brain Injury Veterans' Health Registry to list individuals from Operation Enduring Freedom or Operation Iraqi Freedom with symptoms of traumatic brain injury seeking care or compensation. The Secretary will establish a Traumatic Brain Injury Veterans' Health Registry to list individuals from Operation Enduring Freedom or Operation Iraqi Freedom seeking care or compensation. The Registry will include relevant medical data and information on health consequences of military service, with notifications on research developments. The Secretary will establish a Traumatic Brain Injury Veterans' Health Registry to list individuals from Operation Enduring Freedom or Operation Iraqi Freedom seeking care or compensation, including relevant medical data and information on health consequences of military service. The Registry will also provide notifications on research developments. Additionally, a clerical amendment will be made to the table of contents in the relevant chapter. Subchapter IX of title 38, United States Code, addresses traumatic brain injury. It includes screening, a comprehensive rehabilitation program, transition offices, and a registry. The Secretary must implement these requirements within 180 days of the enactment of the Act.
